If your resume is getting ignored, hereâ€™s why (and how to fix it) ğŸ‘‡  Back when I was a senior recruiter at  hashtag #Tesla, Iâ€™d scan hundreds of resumes a week. Most of them? Instant pass.  ğŸ‘‰ Not because the person wasnâ€™t qualified, but because their resume was either a mess, too generic, or didnâ€™t show any real impact. As a recruiter, I view resumes fairly often ğŸ˜‹  Hehe, if I can, just a few tips and ideas for those on the employment search? (I am by no means a PRO, this purely my opinion from patterns I and my team see.)  And by all means, ignore everything I say... we enjoy a good laugh ğŸ˜ğŸ˜   Honestly, I would like to spend more time talking with YOU rather than asking about all the gaps or confusion that comes from unfinished or empty resumes. (I hope this finds the right audience ğŸ˜¬!)  So...  1. INTRO - We love an intro! Every Indeed manufactured resume looks generic with the "will relocate anywhere" which, frankly, isn't true. Tell me about you and what your goal is in seeking a new position! This helps me get a head start when I get a blurb about what you want and where you are at in your search.  2. DATES - For the love of all things holy and good and... Clean up your dates, don't leave gaps, and explain temp, contract, or seasonal jobs. We automatically rule out poor job longevity so if you explain the reason behind short-term positions, boom!  3. CONTEXT - Give me context please! Who are you?! Whether you work at a Warehouse, in Construction, or got involved in Manufacturing... it seems that unless you are OCD, most of the time there is a LACK of information on what you actually did on your resume. Keep in mind- sometimes title doesn't match responsibilities. Add leadership skills and certificates to your timeline so we can really see what you have to offer!  4. ERRORS- *clears throat. We pay attention to spelling and grammar errors. I mean, we're here to help update all that for your future employer, but if you catch it, make the change! This includes resume gaps that we want to understand AND inconsistency in punctuation, font, and bullet points. Take a second to review before uploading.  5. SKILLS - Don't let a resume generator do all the work! I want to know what YOU specifically can do and that is not always given proper honor when you allow a hiring site to guess your skills based on your previous roles. Really think about what you have accrued besides the typical additions of "time management" and "customer service." We know you have more to offer!  Just a few thoughts! We would love to give you and your future employer the BEST CHANCE in connecting. â€¦more

The design, layout, and content of your resume are essential for capturing the reader's attention in the first 20 to 30 seconds. Itâ€™s important to approach this task with a clear strategy, focusing on highlighting your skills and experience in a concise and engaging way. Here are a few tips to help you craft the perfect resume:  1. Highlight your accomplishments: If you cut costs, increased revenue, delivered projects ahead of time, or broke company records, your resume is the perfect place to highlight these achievements using numbers and percentages to demonstrate your impact. 2. Call out the value you would bring to the target company: Just like in sports, where the value of a new player is debated, your resume is the place to highlight the value you can bring to a potential employer, using the language that aligns with the job you're applying for. 3. Identify the ways you help solve the companyâ€™s challenges: Just like an infomercial highlights a productâ€™s strengths to solve a problem, your resume should showcase your professional assets and demonstrate how you can address the challenges of the company you're applying to.  The right job for you is out there. We can help get you to it  Click the link below to check out our blog!    â€¦more

Is your resume starting to resemble a novel? ğŸ“š Let's trim that epic down to a compelling short story!  Here's how: 1. Prioritize the Last 10-15 Years: Focus on your most recent experience; hiring managers are more interested in what you've done lately. 2. Highlight Achievements, Not Just Duties: Showcase your impact with quantifiable resultsâ€”think revenue growth, cost savings, or process improvements. 3. Remove Outdated Skills: If it's no longer relevant (e.g., obsolete software), leave it out. 4. Use a Hybrid Resume Format: A skills-focused format helps showcase expertise before listing work history. 5. Tailor for Each Job: Only include roles that are directly relevant. Remember, your resume should be a highlight reel, not a documentary. Keep it concise, relevant, and future-focused to show why you're the best fit for today's job market.  What's your biggest challenge in keeping your resume concise? Let's discuss in the comments!  â€¦more

I hear so many engineers asking about ATS-friendly resumes, so I am going to break it down for you today!  Let's use these tips for writing an ATS-friendly resume:  âœ… Use standard headings: - Stick to common headings like â€œWork Experience,â€ â€œEducation,â€ & "Skills.â€  âœ… Keep formatting simple: - Avoid complex layouts, tables, and graphics that could confuse ATS systems.  âœ… Incorporate keywords: - Strategically incorporate relevant keywords from the job description to ensure your resume matches the job requirements. - Try to match 70-80% of job description language  âœ… Use a professional & readable font: -  Stick to fonts like Arial, Times New Roman, or Calibri to ensure readability.  âœ… Tailor each resume: - Customize your resume for each job application to reflect the specific job requirements.  âœ… Quantify relevant experiences: - Highlight measurable achievements and impactful projects.  Critical resume mistakes to avoid:  âŒ Omit personal details: - Do not include details like age, marital status, or photographs.  âŒ Avoid complex designs: - Skip colourful, overly creative layouts that distract from the main content.  âŒ Exclude irrelevant experiences: - Focus only on relevant, recent experience to keep your resume concise.  âŒ Keep graduate resumes short: - For fresh graduates, limit your resume to one page.  Your resume is your first impression, make sure it is clear, optimized, and ATS-friendly to increase your chances of landing an interview.  âœ… Focus on readability, relevance, and measurable impact. âœ… Use relevant keywords from the job description. âœ… Keep formatting clean and simple (avoid graphics/tables). âœ… Tailor each resume for the role, one-size-fits-all wonâ€™t work. âœ… Want better results? Earning the trust of hiring managers is a steep mountain to climb, yet one that holds the key to effective  hashtag #recruitment. As someone who's been in the thick of it for years, I've navigated this climb and gathered invaluable insights.   Today, I want to share these time-tested tips to help you win over even the toughest of hiring managers:  1. Cultivate a partner mindset ğŸ¤: First things first, you're not just a recruiter, but a strategic partner. Think about it. It's not just about filling a role; it's about understanding the unique requirements of a position, recognizing the team dynamic, and finding a person who fits like a glove.  2. Keep communication clear and consistent ğŸ’¬: You've heard it before, and I'll say it again. Communication is key. Consistently update your hiring manager about the progress you're making, potential hiccups in the pipeline, and candidate feedback. Trust me, they'll appreciate your transparency.  3. Demonstrate market knowledge ğŸ“‘: Show them you know your stuff. Keep abreast of industry trends, shifts in the job market, and salary benchmarks. Knowledge is power, and in this case, it can be the bridge to trust.  4. Go beyond the resume ğŸ“ƒ: When you're presenting a candidate, don't just forward a . Instead, present a comprehensive view of the candidate's skills, experience, and cultural fit. Highlight why you believe they're right for the job. It's all about the details.  Keep these nuggets in your arsenal, and you'll be a hiring manager's dream in no time!  â€¦more

Want to stand out in today's job market? You absolutely need to try these TOTALLY not terrible tips.   Forget the usual advice.  People will try and tell you to tailor your resume for each job, build your network, optimize your LinkedIn profile....blah blah blah.  We all know that doesn't work.  If you REALLY want to grab a recruiter's attention, here's what DEFINTIELY works:  1. Make your resume as long as it needs to be!  Have 20 years of experience?  Document everything and make your resume 12 pages long!  Nothing says "Top candidate" like making recruiters work hard to find the important information.  Bonus points if you use size 8 font for your entire resume!  2. Apply to the same job 37 times!  They'll have to notice you eventually right?  Persistence? Yes.  Stalking? That's for you to decide.  3. Make sure your LinkedIn photo is a selfie from the club!  Employers LOVE a candidate who is the life of the party.  It's great for the culture!  4. Slide into a recruiter's DM's at 2AM and ask for an update on your application.  It's well-timed and will help you stand out because you have a better chance of being noticed as the only person to message them when they are trying to sleep!  I could offer more (great) job searching advice but I don't want to "spill all the tea" in one post.  Do you have any other "great" career advice tips that you would like to share?  Let me know in the comments!  Have a great Saturday everyone!  â€¦more

The secret to landing that dream job? It's so simple.  NEVER USE PDFs FOR YOUR RESUME. Too easy for your prospective hiring manager to open. Make them work for it. Use a weird format like .BMP or .Tiff. This provides an air of mystery to your resume. "What could this be? How the hell do I even open a TARGA file in 2025?" Hiring managers love puzzle solving, so give them something they can really sink their teeth into.  START INTERVIEWS BY REVEALING A TRAGIC FAMILY SECRET: You can make one up if you need to. "My grandpa could have stopped Ted Bundy, but didn't" is a good one. "Every one of my uncles is a horse thief" is more niche, but there's a timeless quality to it. My tip? Have fun with it.  INSIST ON BEING PAID IN RARE JEWELS: Inflation, shmilflation! Sure, it may take a few extra steps, but nothing spends better than a sack full of sapphires, emeralds, and diamonds. Slapping down a topaz at the local five and dime is a real flex.  FORCE YOUR INTERVIEWER TO TAKE A POSITION ON MARTIN LUTHER: Divinely inspired reformer, or blasphemous oaf? Both positions are respectable, but make them take a side, and more importantly, defend it.  END WITH A SONG: Most interviewers end interviews with "Do you have any more questions?" This is when you queue up some music and say, "Just one: do you enjoy Billy Joel's middle period?" That's when you can delight them with a rendition of "Uptown Girl" or "Allentown." Don't go for B-Sides like "Big Man on Mulberry Street" or "Running on Ice" you'll just be wasting everyone's time.  Hope this helps! Feel free to leave your favorite job-landing tip below! â€¦more

âœ¨ğŸ“„ Resume Building 101: Stand Out in 20 Seconds ğŸ“„âœ¨ Did you know that employers typically spend only 20 to 30 seconds looking at a resume? Make every second count with these top tips: 1. Choose the Right Format: Highlight your experiences, skills, and abilities in a format that suits you best. A reverse chronological order is often effective, listing your most recent activities first. 2. Keep It Concise: Aim for a one-page resume with consistent formatting. Use bullet points and simple sentences for clarity. 3. Be Honest: Always be truthful. Employers verify information, and honesty is key. 4. Visual Appeal: Make your resume visually appealing to grab attention. 5. Tailor Your Resume: Customize your resume for each job application. Highlight relevant skills and experiences. 6. Clear Objective: Include a clear resume objective to give employers insight into your interests. 7. Action Verbs: Start sentences with powerful action verbs to make your points impactful. 8. Error-Free: Ensure your resume is free of grammatical, spelling, punctuation, and typographical errors. 9. Use Keywords: Incorporate industry-specific keywords and phrases to make your resume relevant to recruiters. For example, if you're an Accounting major, include 'CPA Eligible by May 2025'. 10. Show Leadership and Achievements: Highlight any leadership roles, achievements, and organizational involvement. Make sure these are also visible on your LinkedIn profile. Another lesson learned from responses I've received to "no thank you" emails sent to applicants: I occasionally get responses from applicants pointing out how relevant their experience is--experience not apparent in their resume. Candidates, make it easy on both sides:  * Customize your resume for every job you apply for. * Look at the skills, responsibilities, and experience in the job posting and then make sure as many of those as possible are explicitly stated in your resume (within the bounds of truth, of course). * Use easy-to-skim bullets. Don't make a recruiter squint through long paragraphs trying to understand your value. * Don't assume that a recruiter understands what your previous roles have involved. If you're applying for a job that requires phone skills, for example, spell out in your resume how you've used phone skills in previous roles.  Doing the above helps a recruiter quickly see your relevance to their job and boosts your chances of getting an interview. A win for all!   â€¦more

ğŸ“ When writing your resume, remember to go beyond mere job descriptions (i.e., what you did day-to-day) and focus on showcasing your accomplishments.  Specifically, think about how you've contributed to your organization's success by making or saving money, furthering its mission and vision, and supporting your colleagues in doing the same.  ğŸš€ While you can allocate a couple of sentences to outline your job responsibilities, the real value lies in emphasizing your achievements through well-crafted bullets.  Remember, your resume is not just a list of tasks you performed in previous roles. It's an opportunity to demonstrate the impact you've had on your past employers and how you can bring value to your future ones.  ğŸ’¼ Highlight quantifiable results: Share how your efforts led to cost savings, revenue growth, or process improvements within your team or organization.  ğŸ¯ Showcase your alignment with the company's mission and vision: Illustrate how your work contributed to advancing the organization's overall goals and objectives.  ğŸ¤ Emphasize collaboration and support: Describe instances where you collaborated with colleagues to achieve shared objectives or helped others achieve their goals.  ğŸ” Tailor your resume for each application: Customize your bullet points to align with the specific job requirements and showcase skills and achievements most relevant to the role.  ğŸ’¡ Use action verbs and metrics: Employ strong action verbs to describe your accomplishments and quantify your contributions with specific numbers, percentages, or metrics.  ğŸ“ˆ Prove your value with real-world examples: Paint a clear picture of your impact by providing concrete examples of successful projects, initiatives, or problem-solving scenarios.  A well-crafted resume not only grabs the attention of recruiters and hiring managers but also sets you apart from other candidates by highlighting your unique contributions. So, remember, it's not just about the roles you've held; it's about what you've achieved and how that will benefit your future employer. Make every word count!  â€¦more

Reassessing Resume Gaps: A Shift in Perspective  To Employers: When evaluating candidates, it's crucial to look beyond resume gaps and recognize the inherent value they may bring. Inspired by HBR, consider these tips for assessing career breaks: - Inquire about the story behind the gap to uncover valuable skills, resilience, or renewed direction. - Emphasize growth over gaps, acknowledging how candidates use this time to upskill, volunteer, or reflect on their career trajectory. - Acknowledge the evolving norm of career breaks post-pandemic, understanding its impact on workers' priorities. - Value authenticity in candidates who address gaps with honesty and confidence, traits they may bring to your team.  Remember, a resume gap signifies more than a pauseâ€”it often symbolizes a period of growth, learning, or life management. Keeping an open mind could lead you to your next exceptional hire.  To Job Seekers: - Address resume gaps directly, focusing on the positive aspects and how they enriched your life or skills. - Highlight personal growth during the gap, showcasing volunteer work, new skills acquired, or realigned goals. - Tailor your explanation to the role, emphasizing how your experiences strengthen your candidacy. - Confidently own your unique career journey, understanding that a gap doesn't define you; it's how you navigate and learn from it that matters.  Have you considered the untapped potential of resume gaps? Individuals with extended breaks have secured remarkable roles by leveraging their distinctive strengths and experiences. The painful truth about ATS "hacks" that no one's talking about...  I see job seekers spending countless hours: âœ”ï¸ Cramming keywords âœ”ï¸ Using white text âœ”ï¸ Creating complex tables âœ”ï¸ Testing "perfect" formatting tricks  Here's the reality: Modern ATS systems are FAR more sophisticated than you think. Those outdated hacks from 2015? They might actually be hurting your chances.  Instead, focus on what truly matters:  Write for humans first, ATS second The hiring manager needs to WANT to read your resume. Clear, compelling achievements beat keyword stuffing every time.  Use clean, standard formatting Simple beats clever. Period. Your beautifully formatted resume means nothing if it's unreadable to human eyes.  Tailor with intention Don't just mirror job descriptions. Understand the role's core needs and demonstrate your relevant impact.  Remember: The goal isn't to "beat" the ATS. It's to reach the hiring manager's desk with a resume that makes them want to meet you.  Pro tip: Want to test your resume? Send it to yourself as a plain text file. If it's readable there, most ATS systems will handle it just fine.  Want to check your resume's ATS score? I often get referrals from colleagues in my network asking me to chat with someone who's going through a job transition. When I meet with them, I share this advice:  Get out of your own head. Whatever the reason for your transition, be confident in who you are. Don't start second-guessing yourself or the reasons for the change. Learn from the past when needed and move forward. Now is not the time for imposter syndrome.  Start by making a list of work that genuinely inspires you. About 70% of high-performing professionals find success by aligning their passion with their profession. What truly brings you joy at work?  Next, make a list of organizations you admire within the geography you want to work. Research these organizations looking for clues that relate to your list. This should include checking their websites, Glassdoor, and asking friends and colleagues. You may discover companies you didn't even know existed.  Start networking. The days of just applying for a job and hoping your resume gets picked are over. Begin by checking your admired organization's LinkedIn page for connections you know, or people who can introduce you to key contacts. Look at open roles that might interest you, but remember, new roles are created all the time when the right person shows up. Doing this can get your resume in front of the actual hiring manager.  Lastly, tell everyone you meet that you're looking for work â€“ even your dog groomer might know of an awesome role through one of their customers (to be clear, you want input from the dog parents, not the dog ğŸ˜Š).  All this will transform your job search from transactional to transformational. Position yourself as a strategic solution, not just a candidate. Organizations invest in professionals who solve complex challenges.  Remember: Companies hire potential, not just past achievements. Highlight your unique value and show how your skills can drive organizational success.  ğŸ… What tips do you have that have worked for you in your search?   â€¦more

With over 250 applications per job opening on average, that resume needs a strategic approach to consistently grab the attention needed to get you in the door.  So, is yours designed for easy consumption and comprehension? If you are only paying attention to what goes in it and not how it is delivered, you might have a problem.  Hiring managers and recruiters spend hours reviewing resumes, their eyes weary and strained. Respect their time by ensuring your resume is easy to read and navigate.  Here are some best practices for making your resume as readable as possible:  ğŸ“œ Use a Clean Design: Stick to professional fonts (like Arial, Calibri, or Times New Roman) and avoid unnecessary graphics or images. Keep font sizes between 10 and 12 points for readability.  ğŸ“œ Structure for Navigation: Use clear headings, bold job titles, and bullet points to guide the reader through your experience. Think of your resume as if it were a map. Navigation cues will help your reader find the information they need quickly.  ğŸ“œ Emphasize White Space: White space isnâ€™t wasted space, it is in fact essential for readability. Like a well-designed advertisement, a resume with balanced white space draws attention to key points and prevents the page from feeling overwhelming. Research done in the graphic design field emphasizes that white space enhances readability and legibility, allowing key information to stand out and reducing cognitive load for the reader.  ğŸ“œ Tailor and Highlight: Place the most relevant achievements and skills at the top of each section. You only have seconds to make an impression, so make those seconds count.  Make no mistake, folks. That resume is supposed to be a marketing tool and not just some laundry list of duties. The design and layout needs to reflect that. Just as advertisers use clean layouts to convey a message quickly, your resumeâ€™s design should allow hiring managers to see your value at a glance.  Whatâ€™s one thing you could do today to make your resume more readable?  â€¦more

Get Your Resume Noticed  8 Key Scannable Points (and What Recruiters REALLY Want to See ) hashtag hashtag    Crafting a resume that gets past the initial screening can feel like cracking a code! Here are the top 8 things recruiters typically scan for (forget page count!):  Location: Make it easy for them to see if you're a local candidate.   Summary/Profile: Briefly showcase your key experiences and what makes you stand out.   Company Name (1-3 sentence summary): Quickly explain what the company did (e.g., "Developed educational software for children" or "Managed social media campaigns for a non-profit").   Title: Highlight the specific role you held (use the same wording as the job description if possible).   Dates: Be transparent about your employment history, including month and year (short stints are okay!).   Metrics: Quantify your achievements whenever possible (e.g., "Increased website traffic by 20%"). Numbers grab attention!   Education: Include it if it's relevant to the job (essential for some roles like doctors or engineers).   Technical Skills (if applicable): List relevant skills, but showcase them further in your bullet points with specific examples.   What else are recruiters looking for?  While "soft skills" aren't the answer this time, here are some recruiter favorites: Clear and concise writing (avoid typos!) ï¸  Strong action verbs that showcase your achievements (e.g., "spearheaded," "managed," "increased")  Tailored content that speaks directly to the job description   P.S. Big Company Work Experience? Be Specific!  If you worked for a giant like Google, mention the specific division or function (e.g., "Google Search Ads team" or "Google Cloud Platform engineering"). This clarifies your unique experience within the vast company.   By focusing on these key elements, you can craft a resume that gets noticed and lands you that interview! â€¦more

Your IT/tech job descriptions might be turning candidates away. ğŸ›‘  This is how to fix them! âœ…  â¡ï¸ 1. Start with a clear job title Avoid jargon or creative titles that confuse candidates. A straightforward job title like "Software Engineer" performs better in search results and aligns with candidate expectations.  â¡ï¸ 2. Include a strong opening summary Summarize the role in 2-3 sentences. Focus on the core purpose of the job and how it contributes to the companyâ€™s goals, keeping it concise and engaging.  â¡ï¸ 3. Outline key responsibilities clearly List the main tasks in bullet points. Be specific to avoid ambiguityâ€”avoid general phrases like "handle IT projects" and specify the exact responsibilities.  â¡ï¸ 4. Focus on day-to-day activities Paint a picture of a typical day in the role. This helps candidates visualize the job and assess if it's the right fit for them.  â¡ï¸ 5. Specify required skills and technologies Clearly list must-have technical skills, such as Python, SQL, or AWS. This filters candidates early and saves time for both parties.  â¡ï¸ 6. Differentiate between â€˜requiredâ€™ and â€˜preferredâ€™ skills Clearly label "must-have" versus "nice-to-have" skills. This helps attract qualified applicants while keeping the door open for those who may have potential.  â¡ï¸ 7. Set realistic expectations for experience levels Be precise about the experience level requiredâ€”whether it's entry-level or senior. Avoid broad terms like "junior" or "experienced" without clear year-based guidelines.  â¡ï¸ 8. Explain the purpose of the role Describe why the role exists and how it fits into the company's broader goals. This provides context and meaning, motivating the right candidates to apply.  â¡ï¸ 9. Highlight career growth opportunities Mention internal development programs or career paths. Candidates want to know how they can progress within your company, especially in a fast-paced industry like IT.  â¡ï¸ 10. Provide a clear reporting structure State who the candidate will report to. This helps candidates understand where the role fits in the organizational hierarchy and clarifies team dynamics.  ... and 14 further must-read tips in the carousel below!  â€¦more

Did you recently get passed over for a role you thought you were a perfect fit for? Job hunting can be a challenging journey, and rejection, while tough, is often part of the process. Instead of letting frustration take over, take a step back and assess your approach. Are there areas where you could refine your strategy? Below are a few insights that might help you turn things around and boost your chances for success.  1. Are You Aiming Too High? One common mistake candidates make is applying for roles that may be slightly out of reach. Itâ€™s natural to want to push for the next level in your career, but are your qualifications truly aligned with the position youâ€™re applying for?  If you find yourself consistently passed over for roles that require more experience or a broader skill set, it might be time to reassess and realign. Consider seeking a company with a clear advancement policy or a position that will help bridge the gap between where you are now and where you want to go. Remember: career growth is a marathon, not a sprint.  2. Have You Updated and Tailored Your Resume? Your resume is the first impression you make on potential employers. Have you taken the time to thoroughly update it before submitting your applications? A rushed, generic resume could be the reason youâ€™re not getting callbacks.  Think carefully about the content youâ€™re showcasing. Are you just listing broad job duties, or are you clearly communicating your achievements and the value you've added in your previous roles? Employers want to see specific examples of how youâ€™ve contributed to the success of your past organizations. Instead of simply stating â€œresponsible for managing a team,â€ try adding more depth: â€œLed a team of 8 to successfully implement a project that resulted in a 15% increase in operational efficiency.â€  Refine each bullet point, focusing on accomplishments and measurable outcomes that highlight your unique value.  3. Are You Preparing for Interviews? Winging it simply wonâ€™t cut it. The competition is fierce, and preparation is key. If youâ€™re not taking the time to prepare for interviews, youâ€™re missing out on one of your best chances to shine.  Think about your most significant career achievementsâ€”those moments that truly made an impact at your previous companies. Be ready to share specific metrics, numbers, and examples that demonstrate your value.  Itâ€™s also important to keep your answers concise. Hiring managers often have limited time, so make sure youâ€™re answering questions thoroughly without going off on tangents. Practice telling your stories in a clear, impactful way that highlights your expertise while remaining focused on the relevant details.  4. Bonus: Explore Interview Tips from Experts If youâ€™re feeling stuck or unsure about how to best prepare for interviews, consider checking out resources like Janet Jonesâ€™ profile for a series of valuable tips on acing interviews. â€¦more

Here are my top tips to make your resume stand out!! The goal is clarity and readability. A well-organised, professional resume creates a positive first impression and helps employers quickly see why you're a strong candidate.  Over the next few weeks, I'll also provide tips on what to avoid including in your resume and seek your input on some debatable topics you might believe should be included.  START WITH THE BASICS - Create a clear, professional header with your name, in a larger font, (your header is the first thing employers will notice) and include in a smaller font your phone number and email for easy readability.  SUMMARY - Include a brief summary under your header highlighting your skills, experience, and career goals to showcase and make a strong first impression that youâ€™re the right fit for the job.  SKILLS - Highlight relevant expertise here, tailoring them to the job description and including transferable skills.  HIGHLIGHT YOUR ACHIEVEMENTS AND EDUCATION- List your degrees, certifications, courses, languages, awards, key achievements, professional memberships, accreditations, and volunteer work.  SOFTWARE â€“ List all software programs youâ€™ve used in a separate section under your achievements.  CAREER SUMMARY TABLE â€“ Provide a VERY BRIEF snapshot of your past roles under your listed software, including job title, company, and dates worked. Start with your most recent roles, and include your expanded detailed tasks separately on the following pages.  EMPLOYMENT HISTORY â¦¿ Include company name, job title, promotions, exact dates, and if a permanent or a contract role. â¦¿ Keep your resume concise - 1-3 pages max, or up to 4 if you have over 20 years of experience. List the last 15 years of experience in reverse order, condensing older roles past 15 years unless they are relevant to the job. â¦¿ Dot point tasks - Write in first person without "I," e.g., â€œScheduled and organised client appointments.â€ â¦¿ Make it precise and measurable - saying â€œincreased sales by 20%â€ is more impactful than â€œimproved salesâ€, instead of â€œupdating clients,â€ say â€œupdated 60 clients weekly.â€ â¦¿ Include specific skills and highlight keywords from the job description in your resume to showcase your relevant experience. â¦¿ Briefly explain employment gaps, whether due to travel, study, COVID, redundancy, family, or other reasons.  FORMATTING - Use a consistent 10-12 pt font, bold headers only, bullet points for tasks, and a professional font like Times New Roman or Arial. If using lines, keep them thin and light-coloured.  PROOFREAD â€“ Print or read your resume aloud to spot errors, and have a detail-oriented friend review it.  FINISHING TOUCHES - Name it properly, using your name followed by "Resumeâ€ and save your resume as a PDF to maintain its format.  "MOST IMPORTANTLY", BE HONEST - Honesty is key to your resume. Dishonesty can harm your chances and reputation. Stay truthful! â€¦more

Here are some common resume pitfalls transitioning military job seekers fall into:  ğŸš© 1. The â€˜One-Size-Fits-Allâ€™ Resume  Using the same generic resume for every job application is a surefire way to get ignored.  Solution: Tailor your resume to each job by aligning your skills and experience with the job description.  ğŸš© 2. No Metrics, No Proof  Saying you "improved processes" in the military is vague. The Job Description Copy-Paste Trap  Regurgitating your job duties from a military or corporate role isn't compelling.  Solution: Translate responsibilities into accomplishments. Hiring managers want to know how you made an impact, not just what you were assigned to do. Make sure to use action verbs, metrics, and show results.  ğŸš© 4. Too Much Military/Career Jargon  Don't use military jargon and acronyms that civilians don't understand. If your resume reads like a mission report, it wonâ€™t resonate with civilian recruiters.  Solution: Simplify terminology and explain how your skills transfer to the industry youâ€™re targeting.  ğŸš© 5. Keyword Deficiency  Many resumes get rejected by recruiters because you are not proving how you meet the skills nor address the key words listed in the job description.  Solution: Don't just list all of your previous job responsibilities, use relevant industry keywords and skills from the job description, and SHOW how you've done THAT thing they want you to know how to do.  A resume isnâ€™t just a piece of paper; itâ€™s your personal marketing document.  Avoid these mistakes, and youâ€™ll get closer to landing an interview.  Maloney out! âœŒ     â€¦more

The Truth Behind 6 Resume Myths ğŸ”Š   Thereâ€™s a lot of resume â€œwisdomâ€ floating around the internetâ€”but not all of it is accurate. Your Resume Should Be "Unique" A flashy, one-of-a-kind resume isnâ€™t necessary unless youâ€™re in a creative field. Focus on clarity and relevance instead of gimmicks.  5. When I started looking for a job, people said I should apply to a lot of them. But it didn't work out that way. I applied to many jobs and often got no response.  Why? Because when we rush, we sometimes miss important details about what the job needs. It's like trying to hit a target without looking.  Instead of applying to tons of jobs randomly, it's better to focus on a few. Take time to understand what the job is about and what the company wants. Then, change your resume to match that. Make it fit what the company is looking for.  It's not about sending out a bunch of resumesâ€”it's about sending the right ones. Quality is more important than quantity. If you match your resume with the job, you're more likely to get a call.  So, don't worry about applying everywhere. It's not a race. Take your time, understand the job, and then make your move. It's about being smart, not just being fast.  â€¦more

CV/Resume Building: Your First Step to Career Success   Your CV is often the first impression you make with a potential employer. Yet, many job seekers find themselves struggling with screening tests and not getting the calls they hope for. Instead of spending big on CV-building services, I believe the real investment is in timeâ€”and leveraging accessible tools like Canva, Adobe, or even simple MS Word. Here are a few key tips to help you boost your CVâ€™s chances of passing those screening hurdles:  1. Keep it Precise - Especially for freshers, itâ€™s tempting to include everything. But remember, less is more. Seek advice from professionals in your field or a consultant to streamline your content and keep it relevant.  2. Leverage AI Tools - Donâ€™t miss out on the power of design! Use AI platforms to give your CV a polished, modern look. Plenty of templates are available, and a well-designed CV stands out.  3. Formatting Matters - Ensure your CV is easy to read. Poor formattingâ€”like mismatched fonts, inconsistent alignments, and heavy bordersâ€”can overwhelm the reader. Keep it clean and simple.  4. Spell Check, Always - A CV with spelling or grammatical errors sends the wrong message. Always double-check and, if possible, ask someone else to review it too.  5. Highlight Relevant Interests & Achievements - Tailor your CV to the role you're applying for. Sure, your singing talent is great, but if youâ€™re applying for a finance role, highlighting your interest in business, finance, or the stock market will capture the recruiterâ€™s attention.  || Brownie Tip ||  Use an ATS-Friendly Format - Here's a tip most people don't knowâ€”make sure your CV is ATS-friendly (Applicant Tracking System). Many companies use ATS to filter CVs before they even reach a hiring manager. Stick to standard fonts, avoid images or complex formatting, and use keywords from the job description to increase your chances of passing the automated screening.  Remember, a well-crafted CV isnâ€™t just a list of qualificationsâ€”itâ€™s your story in a nutshell. Spend the time to make it shine, and youâ€™ll find yourself one step closer to that dream job.  Huge thanks tofor sharing her insights on the concept of "ATS/STAR format." I really appreciate the knowledge and perspective!  â€¦more

DEAR JOB SEEKERS  THIS IS WHAT INCREASES YOUR CV SCORE ON THE APPLICANT TRACKING SYSTEM (ATS)  1) SKILLS: You can either have skills in your career objective, job bullet points, separate section or you can have skills in all the above mentioned.  2) LINKEDIN URL: Adding a hyperlink to your Linkedin Profile will help you share information about yourself that might be too much for your CV.  3) CONTACT NUMBER AND E-MAIL ADDRESS Tip: Employers will use either of these two to communicate, make sure the email address spelling is correct and the numbers arenâ€™t swapped around.  4) FILE NAME: Always use your First Name and Surname, using anything else might cause your CV to be discarded or marked off as suspicious.  5) FILE SIZE The file must be under 2 mb. If your CV is bigger than 2 mb you need to remove attachments (copies of qualifications, cover page pictures, photos) or simply re-save it in a different format that will allow for file compression.  6) FILE TYPE: The recommended file type to use is PDF (Not scanned), you must be able to highlight the text. Word can be used as well but PDF will cause the least problems.  7) DATE FORMATTING: Include the month and year for both the start and the end date, the most recent experience being at the top going down.  Have a productive day job seekers, youâ€™re all winners for not giving up!  â€¦more

I often get referrals from colleagues in my network asking me to chat with someone who's going through a job transition. When I meet with them, I share this advice:  Get out of your own head. Whatever the reason for your transition, be confident in who you are. Don't start second-guessing yourself or the reasons for the change. Learn from the past when needed and move forward. Now is not the time for imposter syndrome.  Start by making a list of work that genuinely inspires you. About 70% of high-performing professionals find success by aligning their passion with their profession. What truly brings you joy at work?  Next, make a list of organizations you admire within the geography you want to work. Research these organizations looking for clues that relate to your list. This should include checking their websites, Glassdoor, and asking friends and colleagues. You may discover companies you didn't even know existed.  Start networking. The days of just applying for a job and hoping your resume gets picked are over. Begin by checking your admired organization's LinkedIn page for connections you know, or people who can introduce you to key contacts. Look at open roles that might interest you, but remember, new roles are created all the time when the right person shows up. Doing this can get your resume in front of the actual hiring manager.  Lastly, tell everyone you meet that you're looking for work â€“ even your dog groomer might know of an awesome role through one of their customers (to be clear, you want input from the dog parents, not the dog ğŸ˜Š).  All this will transform your job search from transactional to transformational. Position yourself as a strategic solution, not just a candidate. Organizations invest in professionals who solve complex challenges.  Remember: Companies hire potential, not just past achievements. Highlight your unique value and show how your skills can drive organizational success.  ğŸ… What tips do you have that have worked for you in your search?   â€¦more

The secret to landing that dream job? It's so simple.  NEVER USE PDFs FOR YOUR RESUME. Too easy for your prospective hiring manager to open. Make them work for it. Use a weird format like .BMP or .Tiff. This provides an air of mystery to your resume. "What could this be? How the hell do I even open a TARGA file in 2025?" Hiring managers love puzzle solving, so give them something they can really sink their teeth into.  START INTERVIEWS BY REVEALING A TRAGIC FAMILY SECRET: You can make one up if you need to. "My grandpa could have stopped Ted Bundy, but didn't" is a good one. "Every one of my uncles is a horse thief" is more niche, but there's a timeless quality to it. My tip? Have fun with it.  INSIST ON BEING PAID IN RARE JEWELS: Inflation, shmilflation! Sure, it may take a few extra steps, but nothing spends better than a sack full of sapphires, emeralds, and diamonds. Slapping down a topaz at the local five and dime is a real flex.  FORCE YOUR INTERVIEWER TO TAKE A POSITION ON MARTIN LUTHER: Divinely inspired reformer, or blasphemous oaf? Both positions are respectable, but make them take a side, and more importantly, defend it.  END WITH A SONG: Most interviewers end interviews with "Do you have any more questions?" This is when you queue up some music and say, "Just one: do you enjoy Billy Joel's middle period?" That's when you can delight them with a rendition of "Uptown Girl" or "Allentown." Don't go for B-Sides like "Big Man on Mulberry Street" or "Running on Ice" you'll just be wasting everyone's time.  Hope this helps! Feel free to leave your favorite job-landing tip below! â€¦more

Want to stand out in today's job market? You absolutely need to try these TOTALLY not terrible tips.   Forget the usual advice.  People will try and tell you to tailor your resume for each job, build your network, optimize your LinkedIn profile....blah blah blah.  We all know that doesn't work.  If you REALLY want to grab a recruiter's attention, here's what DEFINTIELY works:  1. Make your resume as long as it needs to be!  Have 20 years of experience?  Document everything and make your resume 12 pages long!  Nothing says "Top candidate" like making recruiters work hard to find the important information.  Bonus points if you use size 8 font for your entire resume!  2. Apply to the same job 37 times!  They'll have to notice you eventually right?  Persistence? Yes.  Stalking? That's for you to decide.  3. Make sure your LinkedIn photo is a selfie from the club!  Employers LOVE a candidate who is the life of the party.  It's great for the culture!  4. Slide into a recruiter's DM's at 2AM and ask for an update on your application.  It's well-timed and will help you stand out because you have a better chance of being noticed as the only person to message them when they are trying to sleep!  I could offer more (great) job searching advice but I don't want to "spill all the tea" in one post.  Do you have any other "great" career advice tips that you would like to share?  Let me know in the comments!  Have a great Saturday everyone!  â€¦more

I see job seekers spending countless hours: âœ”ï¸ Cramming keywords âœ”ï¸ Using white text âœ”ï¸ Creating complex tables âœ”ï¸ Testing "perfect" formatting tricks  Here's the reality: Modern ATS systems are FAR more sophisticated than you think. Instead, focus on what truly matters:  Write for humans first, ATS second The hiring manager needs to WANT to read your resume. Clear, compelling achievements beat keyword stuffing every time. This is great advice. For any of my connections in transition I 100% endorse this guidance, as well as Keri and her team.

Reassessing Resume Gaps: A Shift in Perspective  To Employers: When evaluating candidates, it's crucial to look beyond resume gaps and recognize the inherent value they may bring. Inspired by HBR, consider these tips for assessing career breaks: - Inquire about the story behind the gap to uncover valuable skills, resilience, or renewed direction. - Emphasize growth over gaps, acknowledging how candidates use this time to upskill, volunteer, or reflect on their career trajectory. - Acknowledge the evolving norm of career breaks post-pandemic, understanding its impact on workers' priorities. - Value authenticity in candidates who address gaps with honesty and confidence, traits they may bring to your team.  Remember, a resume gap signifies more than a pauseâ€”it often symbolizes a period of growth, learning, or life management. Keeping an open mind could lead you to your next exceptional hire.  To Job Seekers: - Address resume gaps directly, focusing on the positive aspects and how they enriched your life or skills. - Highlight personal growth during the gap, showcasing volunteer work, new skills acquired, or realigned goals. - Tailor your explanation to the role, emphasizing how your experiences strengthen your candidacy. - Confidently own your unique career journey, understanding that a gap doesn't define you; it's how you navigate and learn from it that matters.  Have you considered the untapped potential of resume gaps? Individuals with extended breaks have secured remarkable roles by leveraging their distinctive strengths and experiences. Share your insights on uncovering the value within these gaps below!    â™»ï¸ Repost to inspire someone ğŸ”” Follow Kumud Deepali R. for daily hiring and motivational posts! â€¦more

A resume is a document that summarizes your skills, experience, and education. It is typically used to apply for jobs. Here are some tips on how to write a resume: * Choose a format. -â€----------------â€-â€------------- There are three main resume formats: chronological, functional, and combination. A chronological resume lists your work experience in reverse chronological order. A functional resume focuses on your skills and abilities. A combination resume combines elements of both chronological and functional resumes.  * Start with your contact information. --------------------------------------------------------------- This includes your name, address, phone number, and email address. * Write a resume objective or summary. A resume objective is a statement of your career goals. A resume summary is a brief overview of your skills and experience.  * List your work experience. ----------------â€------------------------------- For each job, include the company name, job title, dates of employment, and a brief description of your responsibilities.  * List your education. ------------------------------------- Include the name of the school, degree earned, and graduation date.  * List your skills. ------------------------------ This can include both hard skills (such as computer skills) and soft skills (such as communication skills).  * Proofread your resume carefully. ----------------â€----------------------------------------- Make sure there are no typos or grammatical errors.  * Tailor your resume to the specific job you are applying for. ------------------â€----------------------------------------------------- Highlight the skills and experience that are most relevant to the job. Here are some additional tips: * Use action verbs to describe your accomplishments. * Quantify your accomplishments whenever possible. * Keep your resume concise and easy to read. * Use a professional font and layout. -----------------------------------â€---------------------------------- â€¦more

The most common resume mistake I see when working with people:  Including a measurable result  ... that you literally can't measure.  ChatGPT does a great job pulling measurable results to put in your resume when you type in this prompt:  "What are some measurable accomplishments JOB POSITION can put in their resume?"  But it'll give you ideas that are clearly ChatGPT'd.  "Improved time from order to serving food by 25%"  Did you really time every order and calculate how much your "tailored customer service strategy reduced xyz"?  ...and was it really exactly a 25% increase?  Make sure you pick results that are measurable & more importantly TRUE  You can fully expect the interviewer to press you on "how exactly did you achieve this result?" ğŸ’¡ Tips for Crafting a Winning Resume! ğŸš€  Your resume is your personal marketing tool. It needs to capture attention and showcase your skills and experience in the best light possible. Here are some essential tips to make your resume stand out:  1. Clear Contact Information Make sure your name, phone number, email address, and LinkedIn profile are easy to find. If you have a personal website or portfolio, include that too!  2. Compelling Professional Summary Kick things off with a brief but powerful summary of your experience, strengths, and career goals. This sets the tone for the rest of your resume.  3. Tailored Skills Section List relevant skills for the job you're applying for. Focus on a balance of both hard and soft skills that match the role.  4. Achievements Over Responsibilities Instead of just listing job duties, highlight your key achievements. Quantify your successes with numbers (e.g., increased sales by 30%, led a team of 5).  5. Experience That Shows Impact Describe your roles using action verbs and focus on the impact you made. This will demonstrate your contribution and value to potential employers.  6. Keep It Concise A resume should be no longer than 1-2 pages. Be concise and cut out unnecessary information. Employers often skim resumes, so make it easy for them to spot key details.  7. Education & Certifications List your degrees, certifications, and any additional training relevant to the job. Be sure to include dates and institutions.  8. Use Keywords Many companies use Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS) to scan resumes. Include keywords from the job description to ensure your resume gets noticed.  9. Formatting Is Key Keep your resume clean, professional, and easy to read. Use bullet points, bold for headings, and leave enough white space to make it visually appealing.  10. Proofread, Proofread, Proofread! Typos can make a bad impression! Always proofread your resume (or ask a friend) to catch any errors.  Remember, your resume is often the first impression a recruiter or hiring manager gets of you, make it count! ğŸŒŸ    â€¦more

Top 5 resume tips that get you interviews:  1. Lead with the section of your resume with the most value.  Example: if you don't have any experience but have a Masters in Business Analytics, start your resume with your education section.  2. Show specific, numeric impact.  Example: Increased gross revenue by 3% as measure by...  âŒ don't use generic or fake percentages like 20% or 50%. If you cant measure impact, don't use a percentage.  3. Only include skills that you can validate.  Example: If you include Machine Learning in your skills section, you better have some machine learning project or experience in your resume.  4. Add the title you want to be on your resume.  Example: if you have done data analytics at a previous job, but you worked in operations, ask your previous manager if you can change the job title to data analyst on your linkedin and resume.  5. Use ğ—¯ğ—¼ğ—¹ğ—±ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ strategically.  âŒ don't bold skills âœ… bold your impact or outcome of a project  what important resume tips am I missing?  â€¦more

As a recruiter, I view resumes fairly often ğŸ˜‹  Hehe, if I can, just a few tips and ideas for those on the employment search? (I am by no means a PRO, this purely my opinion from patterns I and my team see.)  And by all means, ignore everything I say... we enjoy a good laugh ğŸ˜ğŸ˜   Honestly, I would like to spend more time talking with YOU rather than asking about all the gaps or confusion that comes from unfinished or empty resumes. (I hope this finds the right audience ğŸ˜¬!)  So...  1. INTRO - We love an intro! Every Indeed manufactured resume looks generic with the "will relocate anywhere" which, frankly, isn't true. Tell me about you and what your goal is in seeking a new position! This helps me get a head start when I get a blurb about what you want and where you are at in your search.  2. DATES - For the love of all things holy and good and... Clean up your dates, don't leave gaps, and explain temp, contract, or seasonal jobs. We automatically rule out poor job longevity so if you explain the reason behind short-term positions, boom!  3. CONTEXT - Give me context please! Who are you?! Whether you work at a Warehouse, in Construction, or got involved in Manufacturing... it seems that unless you are OCD, most of the time there is a LACK of information on what you actually did on your resume. Keep in mind- sometimes title doesn't match responsibilities. Add leadership skills and certificates to your timeline so we can really see what you have to offer!  4. ERRORS- *clears throat. We pay attention to spelling and grammar errors. I mean, we're here to help update all that for your future employer, but if you catch it, make the change! This includes resume gaps that we want to understand AND inconsistency in punctuation, font, and bullet points. Take a second to review before uploading.  5. SKILLS - Don't let a resume generator do all the work! I want to know what YOU specifically can do and that is not always given proper honor when you allow a hiring site to guess your skills based on your previous roles. Really think about what you have accrued besides the typical additions of "time management" and "customer service." We know you have more to offer!  Just a few thoughts! We would love to give you and your future employer the BEST CHANCE in connecting. â€¦more

The design, layout, and content of your resume are essential for capturing the reader's attention in the first 20 to 30 seconds. Itâ€™s important to approach this task with a clear strategy, focusing on highlighting your skills and experience in a concise and engaging way. Here are a few tips to help you craft the perfect resume:  1. Highlight your accomplishments: If you cut costs, increased revenue, delivered projects ahead of time, or broke company records, your resume is the perfect place to highlight these achievements using numbers and percentages to demonstrate your impact. 2. Call out the value you would bring to the target company: Just like in sports, where the value of a new player is debated, your resume is the place to highlight the value you can bring to a potential employer, using the language that aligns with the job you're applying for. 3. Identify the ways you help solve the companyâ€™s challenges: Just like an infomercial highlights a productâ€™s strengths to solve a problem, your resume should showcase your professional assets and demonstrate how you can address the challenges of the company you're applying to. Is your resume starting to resemble a novel? ğŸ“š Let's trim that epic down to a compelling short story!  Here's how: 1. Prioritize the Last 10-15 Years: Focus on your most recent experience; hiring managers are more interested in what you've done lately. 2. Highlight Achievements, Not Just Duties: Showcase your impact with quantifiable resultsâ€”think revenue growth, cost savings, or process improvements. 3. Remove Outdated Skills: If it's no longer relevant (e.g., obsolete software), leave it out. 4. Use a Hybrid Resume Format: A skills-focused format helps showcase expertise before listing work history. 5. Tailor for Each Job: Only include roles that are directly relevant. Remember, your resume should be a highlight reel, not a documentary. Keep it concise, relevant, and future-focused to show why you're the best fit for today's job market. Want to stand out in today's job market? You absolutely need to try these TOTALLY not terrible tips.   Forget the usual advice.  People will try and tell you to tailor your resume for each job, build your network, optimize your LinkedIn profile....blah blah blah.  We all know that doesn't work.  If you REALLY want to grab a recruiter's attention, here's what DEFINTIELY works:  1. Make your resume as long as it needs to be!  Have 20 years of experience?  Document everything and make your resume 12 pages long!  Nothing says "Top candidate" like making recruiters work hard to find the important information.  Bonus points if you use size 8 font for your entire resume!  2. Apply to the same job 37 times!  They'll have to notice you eventually right?  Persistence? Yes.  Stalking? That's for you to decide.  3. Make sure your LinkedIn photo is a selfie from the club!  Employers LOVE a candidate who is the life of the party.  It's great for the culture!  4. Slide into a recruiter's DM's at 2AM and ask for an update on your application.  It's well-timed and will help you stand out because you have a better chance of being noticed as the only person to message them when they are trying to sleep!  I could offer more (great) job searching advice but I don't want to "spill all the tea" in one post.  Do you have any other "great" career advice tips that you would like to share?  Let me know in the comments!  Have a great Saturday everyone!  â€¦more

The secret to landing that dream job? It's so simple.  NEVER USE PDFs FOR YOUR RESUME. Too easy for your prospective hiring manager to open. Make them work for it. Use a weird format like .BMP or .Tiff. This provides an air of mystery to your resume. "What could this be? How the hell do I even open a TARGA file in 2025?" Hiring managers love puzzle solving, so give them something they can really sink their teeth into.  START INTERVIEWS BY REVEALING A TRAGIC FAMILY SECRET: You can make one up if you need to. "My grandpa could have stopped Ted Bundy, but didn't" is a good one. "Every one of my uncles is a horse thief" is more niche, but there's a timeless quality to it. My tip? Have fun with it.  INSIST ON BEING PAID IN RARE JEWELS: Inflation, shmilflation! Sure, it may take a few extra steps, but nothing spends better than a sack full of sapphires, emeralds, and diamonds. Slapping down a topaz at the local five and dime is a real flex.  FORCE YOUR INTERVIEWER TO TAKE A POSITION ON MARTIN LUTHER: Divinely inspired reformer, or blasphemous oaf? Both positions are respectable, but make them take a side, and more importantly, defend it.  END WITH A SONG: Most interviewers end interviews with "Do you have any more questions?" This is when you queue up some music and say, "Just one: do you enjoy Billy Joel's middle period?" That's when you can delight them with a rendition of "Uptown Girl" or "Allentown." Don't go for B-Sides like "Big Man on Mulberry Street" or "Running on Ice" you'll just be wasting everyone's time.  Hope this helps! Feel free to leave your favorite job-landing tip below! â€¦more

âœ¨ğŸ“„ Resume Building 101: Stand Out in 20 Seconds ğŸ“„âœ¨ Did you know that employers typically spend only 20 to 30 seconds looking at a resume? Make every second count with these top tips: 1. Show Leadership and Achievements: Highlight any leadership roles, achievements, and organizational involvement. Make sure these are also visible on your LinkedIn profile. Another lesson learned from responses I've received to "no thank you" emails sent to applicants: I occasionally get responses from applicants pointing out how relevant their experience is--experience not apparent in their resume. Candidates, make it easy on both sides:  * Customize your resume for every job you apply for. * Look at the skills, responsibilities, and experience in the job posting and then make sure as many of those as possible are explicitly stated in your resume (within the bounds of truth, of course). * Use easy-to-skim bullets. Don't make a recruiter squint through long paragraphs trying to understand your value. * Don't assume that a recruiter understands what your previous roles have involved. If you're applying for a job that requires phone skills, for example, spell out in your resume how you've used phone skills in previous roles.  Doing the above helps a recruiter quickly see your relevance to their job and boosts your chances of getting an interview. A win for all!   â€¦more

ğŸ“ When writing your resume, remember to go beyond mere job descriptions (i.e., what you did day-to-day) and focus on showcasing your accomplishments. It's an opportunity to demonstrate the impact you've had on your past employers and how you can bring value to your future ones.  ğŸ’¼ Highlight quantifiable results: Share how your efforts led to cost savings, revenue growth, or process improvements within your team or organization.  ğŸ¯ Showcase your alignment with the company's mission and vision: Illustrate how your work contributed to advancing the organization's overall goals and objectives.  ğŸ¤ Emphasize collaboration and support: Describe instances where you collaborated with colleagues to achieve shared objectives or helped others achieve their goals.  ğŸ” Tailor your resume for each application: Customize your bullet points to align with the specific job requirements and showcase skills and achievements most relevant to the role.  ğŸ’¡ Use action verbs and metrics: Employ strong action verbs to describe your accomplishments and quantify your contributions with specific numbers, percentages, or metrics.  ğŸ“ˆ Prove your value with real-world examples: Paint a clear picture of your impact by providing concrete examples of successful projects, initiatives, or problem-solving scenarios.  A well-crafted resume not only grabs the attention of recruiters and hiring managers but also sets you apart from other candidates by highlighting your unique contributions. So, remember, it's not just about the roles you've held; it's about what you've achieved and how that will benefit your future employer. Make every word count!  â€¦more

Reassessing Resume Gaps: A Shift in Perspective  To Employers: When evaluating candidates, it's crucial to look beyond resume gaps and recognize the inherent value they may bring. Inspired by HBR, consider these tips for assessing career breaks: - Inquire about the story behind the gap to uncover valuable skills, resilience, or renewed direction. - Emphasize growth over gaps, acknowledging how candidates use this time to upskill, volunteer, or reflect on their career trajectory. - Acknowledge the evolving norm of career breaks post-pandemic, understanding its impact on workers' priorities. - Value authenticity in candidates who address gaps with honesty and confidence, traits they may bring to your team.  Remember, a resume gap signifies more than a pauseâ€”it often symbolizes a period of growth, learning, or life management. Keeping an open mind could lead you to your next exceptional hire.  To Job Seekers: - Address resume gaps directly, focusing on the positive aspects and how they enriched your life or skills. - Highlight personal growth during the gap, showcasing volunteer work, new skills acquired, or realigned goals. - Tailor your explanation to the role, emphasizing how your experiences strengthen your candidacy. - Confidently own your unique career journey, understanding that a gap doesn't define you; it's how you navigate and learn from it that matters.  Have you considered the untapped potential of resume gaps? Individuals with extended breaks have secured remarkable roles by leveraging their distinctive strengths and experiences. Share your insights on uncovering the value within these gaps below!    â™»ï¸ Repost to inspire someone ğŸ”” Follow Kumud Deepali R. for daily hiring and motivational posts! â€¦more

The painful truth about ATS "hacks" that no one's talking about...  I see job seekers spending countless hours: âœ”ï¸ Cramming keywords âœ”ï¸ Using white text âœ”ï¸ Creating complex tables âœ”ï¸ Testing "perfect" formatting tricks  Here's the reality: Modern ATS systems are FAR more sophisticated than you think. Those outdated hacks from 2015? They might actually be hurting your chances.  Instead, focus on what truly matters:  Write for humans first, ATS second The hiring manager needs to WANT to read your resume. Clear, compelling achievements beat keyword stuffing every time.  Use clean, standard formatting Simple beats clever. Period. Your beautifully formatted resume means nothing if it's unreadable to human eyes.  Tailor with intention Don't just mirror job descriptions. Understand the role's core needs and demonstrate your relevant impact.  Remember: The goal isn't to "beat" the ATS. It's to reach the hiring manager's desk with a resume that makes them want to meet you.  Pro tip: Want to test your resume? Send it to yourself as a plain text file. If it's readable there, most ATS systems will handle it just fine.  Want to check your resume's ATS score? I often get referrals from colleagues in my network asking me to chat with someone who's going through a job transition. When I meet with them, I share this advice:  Get out of your own head. Whatever the reason for your transition, be confident in who you are. Don't start second-guessing yourself or the reasons for the change. Learn from the past when needed and move forward. Now is not the time for imposter syndrome.  Start by making a list of work that genuinely inspires you. About 70% of high-performing professionals find success by aligning their passion with their profession. What truly brings you joy at work?  Next, make a list of organizations you admire within the geography you want to work. Research these organizations looking for clues that relate to your list. This should include checking their websites, Glassdoor, and asking friends and colleagues. You may discover companies you didn't even know existed.  Start networking. The days of just applying for a job and hoping your resume gets picked are over. Begin by checking your admired organization's LinkedIn page for connections you know, or people who can introduce you to key contacts. Look at open roles that might interest you, but remember, new roles are created all the time when the right person shows up. Doing this can get your resume in front of the actual hiring manager.  Lastly, tell everyone you meet that you're looking for work â€“ even your dog groomer might know of an awesome role through one of their customers (to be clear, you want input from the dog parents, not the dog ğŸ˜Š).  All this will transform your job search from transactional to transformational. Position yourself as a strategic solution, not just a candidate. Organizations invest in professionals who solve complex challenges.  Remember: Companies hire potential, not just past achievements. Highlight your unique value and show how your skills can drive organizational success.  ğŸ… What tips do you have that have worked for you in your search?   â€¦more

With over 250 applications per job opening on average, that resume needs a strategic approach to consistently grab the attention needed to get you in the door.  So, is yours designed for easy consumption and comprehension? If you are only paying attention to what goes in it and not how it is delivered, you might have a problem.  Hiring managers and recruiters spend hours reviewing resumes, their eyes weary and strained. Respect their time by ensuring your resume is easy to read and navigate.  Here are some best practices for making your resume as readable as possible:  ğŸ“œ Use a Clean Design: Stick to professional fonts (like Arial, Calibri, or Times New Roman) and avoid unnecessary graphics or images. Keep font sizes between 10 and 12 points for readability.  ğŸ“œ Structure for Navigation: Use clear headings, bold job titles, and bullet points to guide the reader through your experience. Think of your resume as if it were a map. Navigation cues will help your reader find the information they need quickly.  ğŸ“œ Emphasize White Space: White space isnâ€™t wasted space, it is in fact essential for readability. Like a well-designed advertisement, a resume with balanced white space draws attention to key points and prevents the page from feeling overwhelming. Research done in the graphic design field emphasizes that white space enhances readability and legibility, allowing key information to stand out and reducing cognitive load for the reader.  ğŸ“œ Tailor and Highlight: Place the most relevant achievements and skills at the top of each section. You only have seconds to make an impression, so make those seconds count.  Make no mistake, folks. That resume is supposed to be a marketing tool and not just some laundry list of duties. The design and layout needs to reflect that. Just as advertisers use clean layouts to convey a message quickly, your resumeâ€™s design should allow hiring managers to see your value at a glance.  Whatâ€™s one thing you could do today to make your resume more readable?  â€¦more

Get Your Resume Noticed  8 Key Scannable Points (and What Recruiters REALLY Want to See ) hashtag hashtag    Crafting a resume that gets past the initial screening can feel like cracking a code! Here are the top 8 things recruiters typically scan for (forget page count!):  Location: Make it easy for them to see if you're a local candidate.   Summary/Profile: Briefly showcase your key experiences and what makes you stand out.   Company Name (1-3 sentence summary): Quickly explain what the company did (e.g., "Developed educational software for children" or "Managed social media campaigns for a non-profit").   Title: Highlight the specific role you held (use the same wording as the job description if possible).   Dates: Be transparent about your employment history, including month and year (short stints are okay!).   Metrics: Quantify your achievements whenever possible (e.g., "Increased website traffic by 20%"). Numbers grab attention!   Education: Include it if it's relevant to the job (essential for some roles like doctors or engineers).   Technical Skills (if applicable): List relevant skills, but showcase them further in your bullet points with specific examples.   What else are recruiters looking for?  While "soft skills" aren't the answer this time, here are some recruiter favorites: Clear and concise writing (avoid typos!) ï¸  Strong action verbs that showcase your achievements (e.g., "spearheaded," "managed," "increased")  Tailored content that speaks directly to the job description   P.S. Big Company Work Experience? Be Specific!  If you worked for a giant like Google, mention the specific division or function (e.g., "Google Search Ads team" or "Google Cloud Platform engineering"). This clarifies your unique experience within the vast company.   By focusing on these key elements, you can craft a resume that gets noticed and lands you that interview! â€¦more

Your IT/tech job descriptions might be turning candidates away. ğŸ›‘  This is how to fix them! âœ…  â¡ï¸ 1. Start with a clear job title Avoid jargon or creative titles that confuse candidates. A straightforward job title like "Software Engineer" performs better in search results and aligns with candidate expectations.  â¡ï¸ 2. Include a strong opening summary Summarize the role in 2-3 sentences. Focus on the core purpose of the job and how it contributes to the companyâ€™s goals, keeping it concise and engaging.  â¡ï¸ 3. Outline key responsibilities clearly List the main tasks in bullet points. Be specific to avoid ambiguityâ€”avoid general phrases like "handle IT projects" and specify the exact responsibilities.  â¡ï¸ 4. Focus on day-to-day activities Paint a picture of a typical day in the role. This helps candidates visualize the job and assess if it's the right fit for them.  â¡ï¸ 5. Specify required skills and technologies Clearly list must-have technical skills, such as Python, SQL, or AWS. This filters candidates early and saves time for both parties.  â¡ï¸ 6. Differentiate between â€˜requiredâ€™ and â€˜preferredâ€™ skills Clearly label "must-have" versus "nice-to-have" skills. This helps attract qualified applicants while keeping the door open for those who may have potential.  â¡ï¸ 7. Set realistic expectations for experience levels Be precise about the experience level requiredâ€”whether it's entry-level or senior. Avoid broad terms like "junior" or "experienced" without clear year-based guidelines.  â¡ï¸ 8. Explain the purpose of the role Describe why the role exists and how it fits into the company's broader goals. This provides context and meaning, motivating the right candidates to apply.  â¡ï¸ 9. Highlight career growth opportunities Mention internal development programs or career paths. Candidates want to know how they can progress within your company, especially in a fast-paced industry like IT.  â¡ï¸ 10. Provide a clear reporting structure State who the candidate will report to. This helps candidates understand where the role fits in the organizational hierarchy and clarifies team dynamics.  ... and 14 further must-read tips in the carousel below!  â€¦more

Did you recently get passed over for a role you thought you were a perfect fit for? Job hunting can be a challenging journey, and rejection, while tough, is often part of the process. Instead of letting frustration take over, take a step back and assess your approach. Are there areas where you could refine your strategy? Below are a few insights that might help you turn things around and boost your chances for success.  1. Are You Aiming Too High? One common mistake candidates make is applying for roles that may be slightly out of reach. Itâ€™s natural to want to push for the next level in your career, but are your qualifications truly aligned with the position youâ€™re applying for?  If you find yourself consistently passed over for roles that require more experience or a broader skill set, it might be time to reassess and realign. Consider seeking a company with a clear advancement policy or a position that will help bridge the gap between where you are now and where you want to go. Remember: career growth is a marathon, not a sprint.  2. Have You Updated and Tailored Your Resume? Your resume is the first impression you make on potential employers. Have you taken the time to thoroughly update it before submitting your applications? A rushed, generic resume could be the reason youâ€™re not getting callbacks.  Think carefully about the content youâ€™re showcasing. Are you just listing broad job duties, or are you clearly communicating your achievements and the value you've added in your previous roles? Employers want to see specific examples of how youâ€™ve contributed to the success of your past organizations. Instead of simply stating â€œresponsible for managing a team,â€ try adding more depth: â€œLed a team of 8 to successfully implement a project that resulted in a 15% increase in operational efficiency.â€  Refine each bullet point, focusing on accomplishments and measurable outcomes that highlight your unique value.  3. Are You Preparing for Interviews? Winging it simply wonâ€™t cut it. The competition is fierce, and preparation is key. If youâ€™re not taking the time to prepare for interviews, youâ€™re missing out on one of your best chances to shine.  Think about your most significant career achievementsâ€”those moments that truly made an impact at your previous companies. Be ready to share specific metrics, numbers, and examples that demonstrate your value.  Itâ€™s also important to keep your answers concise. Hiring managers often have limited time, so make sure youâ€™re answering questions thoroughly without going off on tangents. Practice telling your stories in a clear, impactful way that highlights your expertise while remaining focused on the relevant details.  4. Bonus: Explore Interview Tips from Experts If youâ€™re feeling stuck or unsure about how to best prepare for interviews, consider checking out resources like Janet Jonesâ€™ profile for a series of valuable tips on acing interviews. â€¦more

Here are my top tips to make your resume stand out!! The goal is clarity and readability. A well-organised, professional resume creates a positive first impression and helps employers quickly see why you're a strong candidate.  Over the next few weeks, I'll also provide tips on what to avoid including in your resume and seek your input on some debatable topics you might believe should be included.  START WITH THE BASICS - Create a clear, professional header with your name, in a larger font, (your header is the first thing employers will notice) and include in a smaller font your phone number and email for easy readability.  SUMMARY - Include a brief summary under your header highlighting your skills, experience, and career goals to showcase and make a strong first impression that youâ€™re the right fit for the job.  SKILLS - Highlight relevant expertise here, tailoring them to the job description and including transferable skills.  HIGHLIGHT YOUR ACHIEVEMENTS AND EDUCATION- List your degrees, certifications, courses, languages, awards, key achievements, professional memberships, accreditations, and volunteer work.  SOFTWARE â€“ List all software programs youâ€™ve used in a separate section under your achievements.  CAREER SUMMARY TABLE â€“ Provide a VERY BRIEF snapshot of your past roles under your listed software, including job title, company, and dates worked. Start with your most recent roles, and include your expanded detailed tasks separately on the following pages.  EMPLOYMENT HISTORY â¦¿ Include company name, job title, promotions, exact dates, and if a permanent or a contract role. â¦¿ Keep your resume concise - 1-3 pages max, or up to 4 if you have over 20 years of experience. List the last 15 years of experience in reverse order, condensing older roles past 15 years unless they are relevant to the job. â¦¿ Dot point tasks - Write in first person without "I," e.g., â€œScheduled and organised client appointments.â€ â¦¿ Make it precise and measurable - saying â€œincreased sales by 20%â€ is more impactful than â€œimproved salesâ€, instead of â€œupdating clients,â€ say â€œupdated 60 clients weekly.â€ â¦¿ Include specific skills and highlight keywords from the job description in your resume to showcase your relevant experience. â¦¿ Briefly explain employment gaps, whether due to travel, study, COVID, redundancy, family, or other reasons.  FORMATTING - Use a consistent 10-12 pt font, bold headers only, bullet points for tasks, and a professional font like Times New Roman or Arial. If using lines, keep them thin and light-coloured.  PROOFREAD â€“ Print or read your resume aloud to spot errors, and have a detail-oriented friend review it.  FINISHING TOUCHES - Name it properly, using your name followed by "Resumeâ€ and save your resume as a PDF to maintain its format.  "MOST IMPORTANTLY", BE HONEST - Honesty is key to your resume. Dishonesty can harm your chances and reputation. Stay truthful! â€¦more
