Here are some common resume pitfalls transitioning military job seekers fall into:  ğŸš© 1. The â€˜One-Size-Fits-Allâ€™ Resume  Using the same generic resume for every job application is a surefire way to get ignored.  Solution: Tailor your resume to each job by aligning your skills and experience with the job description.  ğŸš© 2. No Metrics, No Proof  Saying you "improved processes" in the military is vague. Saying you "increased efficiency by 30% and reduced costs by $50K" is impactful.  Solution: Use quantifiable achievements to show your value.  ğŸš© 3. The Job Description Copy-Paste Trap  Regurgitating your job duties from a military or corporate role isn't compelling.  Solution: Translate responsibilities into accomplishments. Hiring managers want to know how you made an impact, not just what you were assigned to do. Make sure to use action verbs, metrics, and show results.  ğŸš© 4. Too Much Military/Career Jargon  Don't use military jargon and acronyms that civilians don't understand. If your resume reads like a mission report, it wonâ€™t resonate with civilian recruiters.  Solution: Simplify terminology and explain how your skills transfer to the industry youâ€™re targeting.  ğŸš© 5. Keyword Deficiency  Many resumes get rejected by recruiters because you are not proving how you meet the skills nor address the key words listed in the job description.  Solution: Don't just list all of your previous job responsibilities, use relevant industry keywords and skills from the job description, and SHOW how you've done THAT thing they want you to know how to do. When I started looking for a job, people said I should apply to a lot of them. But it didn't work out that way. I applied to many jobs and often got no response.  Why? Because when we rush, we sometimes miss important details about what the job needs. It's like trying to hit a target without looking.  Instead of applying to tons of jobs randomly, it's better to focus on a few. Take time to understand what the job is about and what the company wants. Then, change your resume to match that. Make it fit what the company is looking for.  It's not about sending out a bunch of resumesâ€”it's about sending the right ones. Quality is more important than quantity. If you match your resume with the job, you're more likely to get a call.  So, don't worry about applying everywhere. It's not a race. Take your time, understand the job, and then make your move. It's about being smart, not just being fast.  â€¦more

CV/Resume Building: Your First Step to Career Success   Your CV is often the first impression you make with a potential employer. Yet, many job seekers find themselves struggling with screening tests and not getting the calls they hope for. Instead of spending big on CV-building services, I believe the real investment is in timeâ€”and leveraging accessible tools like Canva, Adobe, or even simple MS Word. Here are a few key tips to help you boost your CVâ€™s chances of passing those screening hurdles:  1. Keep it Precise - Especially for freshers, itâ€™s tempting to include everything. But remember, less is more. Seek advice from professionals in your field or a consultant to streamline your content and keep it relevant.  2. Leverage AI Tools - Donâ€™t miss out on the power of design! Use AI platforms to give your CV a polished, modern look. Plenty of templates are available, and a well-designed CV stands out.  3. Formatting Matters - Ensure your CV is easy to read. Poor formattingâ€”like mismatched fonts, inconsistent alignments, and heavy bordersâ€”can overwhelm the reader. Keep it clean and simple.  4. Spell Check, Always - A CV with spelling or grammatical errors sends the wrong message. Always double-check and, if possible, ask someone else to review it too.  5. Highlight Relevant Interests & Achievements - Tailor your CV to the role you're applying for. Sure, your singing talent is great, but if youâ€™re applying for a finance role, highlighting your interest in business, finance, or the stock market will capture the recruiterâ€™s attention.  || Brownie Tip ||  Use an ATS-Friendly Format - Here's a tip most people don't knowâ€”make sure your CV is ATS-friendly (Applicant Tracking System). Many companies use ATS to filter CVs before they even reach a hiring manager. Stick to standard fonts, avoid images or complex formatting, and use keywords from the job description to increase your chances of passing the automated screening.  Remember, a well-crafted CV isnâ€™t just a list of qualificationsâ€”itâ€™s your story in a nutshell. Spend the time to make it shine, and youâ€™ll find yourself one step closer to that dream job. DEAR JOB SEEKERS  THIS IS WHAT INCREASES YOUR CV SCORE ON THE APPLICANT TRACKING SYSTEM (ATS)  1) SKILLS: You can either have skills in your career objective, job bullet points, separate section or you can have skills in all the above mentioned.  2) LINKEDIN URL: Adding a hyperlink to your Linkedin Profile will help you share information about yourself that might be too much for your CV.  3) CONTACT NUMBER AND E-MAIL ADDRESS Tip: Employers will use either of these two to communicate, make sure the email address spelling is correct and the numbers arenâ€™t swapped around.  4) FILE NAME: Always use your First Name and Surname, using anything else might cause your CV to be discarded or marked off as suspicious.  5) FILE SIZE The file must be under 2 mb. If your CV is bigger than 2 mb you need to remove attachments (copies of qualifications, cover page pictures, photos) or simply re-save it in a different format that will allow for file compression.  6) FILE TYPE: The recommended file type to use is PDF (Not scanned), you must be able to highlight the text. Word can be used as well but PDF will cause the least problems.  7) DATE FORMATTING: Include the month and year for both the start and the end date, the most recent experience being at the top going down.  Have a productive day job seekers, youâ€™re all winners for not giving up!  â€¦more

I often get referrals from colleagues in my network asking me to chat with someone who's going through a job transition. When I meet with them, I share this advice:  Get out of your own head. Whatever the reason for your transition, be confident in who you are. Don't start second-guessing yourself or the reasons for the change. Learn from the past when needed and move forward. Now is not the time for imposter syndrome.  Start by making a list of work that genuinely inspires you. About 70% of high-performing professionals find success by aligning their passion with their profession. What truly brings you joy at work?  Next, make a list of organizations you admire within the geography you want to work. Research these organizations looking for clues that relate to your list. This should include checking their websites, Glassdoor, and asking friends and colleagues. You may discover companies you didn't even know existed.  Start networking. The days of just applying for a job and hoping your resume gets picked are over. Begin by checking your admired organization's LinkedIn page for connections you know, or people who can introduce you to key contacts. Look at open roles that might interest you, but remember, new roles are created all the time when the right person shows up. Doing this can get your resume in front of the actual hiring manager.  Lastly, tell everyone you meet that you're looking for work â€“ even your dog groomer might know of an awesome role through one of their customers (to be clear, you want input from the dog parents, not the dog ğŸ˜Š).  All this will transform your job search from transactional to transformational. Position yourself as a strategic solution, not just a candidate. Organizations invest in professionals who solve complex challenges.  Remember: Companies hire potential, not just past achievements. Highlight your unique value and show how your skills can drive organizational success.  ğŸ… What tips do you have that have worked for you in your search?   â€¦more

The secret to landing that dream job? It's so simple.  NEVER USE PDFs FOR YOUR RESUME. Too easy for your prospective hiring manager to open. Make them work for it. Use a weird format like .BMP or .Tiff. This provides an air of mystery to your resume. "What could this be? How the hell do I even open a TARGA file in 2025?" Hiring managers love puzzle solving, so give them something they can really sink their teeth into.  START INTERVIEWS BY REVEALING A TRAGIC FAMILY SECRET: You can make one up if you need to. "My grandpa could have stopped Ted Bundy, but didn't" is a good one. "Every one of my uncles is a horse thief" is more niche, but there's a timeless quality to it. My tip? Have fun with it.  INSIST ON BEING PAID IN RARE JEWELS: Inflation, shmilflation! Sure, it may take a few extra steps, but nothing spends better than a sack full of sapphires, emeralds, and diamonds. Slapping down a topaz at the local five and dime is a real flex.  FORCE YOUR INTERVIEWER TO TAKE A POSITION ON MARTIN LUTHER: Divinely inspired reformer, or blasphemous oaf? Both positions are respectable, but make them take a side, and more importantly, defend it.  END WITH A SONG: Most interviewers end interviews with "Do you have any more questions?" This is when you queue up some music and say, "Just one: do you enjoy Billy Joel's middle period?" That's when you can delight them with a rendition of "Uptown Girl" or "Allentown." Don't go for B-Sides like "Big Man on Mulberry Street" or "Running on Ice" you'll just be wasting everyone's time.  Hope this helps! Feel free to leave your favorite job-landing tip below! â€¦more

Want to stand out in today's job market? You absolutely need to try these TOTALLY not terrible tips.   Forget the usual advice.  People will try and tell you to tailor your resume for each job, build your network, optimize your LinkedIn profile....blah blah blah.  We all know that doesn't work.  If you REALLY want to grab a recruiter's attention, here's what DEFINTIELY works:  1. Make your resume as long as it needs to be!  Have 20 years of experience?  Document everything and make your resume 12 pages long!  Nothing says "Top candidate" like making recruiters work hard to find the important information.  Bonus points if you use size 8 font for your entire resume!  2. Apply to the same job 37 times!  They'll have to notice you eventually right?  Persistence? Yes.  Stalking? That's for you to decide.  3. Make sure your LinkedIn photo is a selfie from the club!  Employers LOVE a candidate who is the life of the party.  It's great for the culture!  4. Slide into a recruiter's DM's at 2AM and ask for an update on your application.  It's well-timed and will help you stand out because you have a better chance of being noticed as the only person to message them when they are trying to sleep!  I could offer more (great) job searching advice but I don't want to "spill all the tea" in one post.  Do you have any other "great" career advice tips that you would like to share? Instead, focus on what truly matters:  Write for humans first, ATS second The hiring manager needs to WANT to read your resume. Clear, compelling achievements beat keyword stuffing every time. Tailor with intention Don't just mirror job descriptions. Understand the role's core needs and demonstrate your relevant impact.  Remember: The goal isn't to "beat" the ATS. Reassessing Resume Gaps: A Shift in Perspective  To Employers: When evaluating candidates, it's crucial to look beyond resume gaps and recognize the inherent value they may bring. Inspired by HBR, consider these tips for assessing career breaks: - Inquire about the story behind the gap to uncover valuable skills, resilience, or renewed direction. - Emphasize growth over gaps, acknowledging how candidates use this time to upskill, volunteer, or reflect on their career trajectory. - Acknowledge the evolving norm of career breaks post-pandemic, understanding its impact on workers' priorities. - Value authenticity in candidates who address gaps with honesty and confidence, traits they may bring to your team.  Remember, a resume gap signifies more than a pauseâ€”it often symbolizes a period of growth, learning, or life management. Keeping an open mind could lead you to your next exceptional hire.  To Job Seekers: - Address resume gaps directly, focusing on the positive aspects and how they enriched your life or skills. - Highlight personal growth during the gap, showcasing volunteer work, new skills acquired, or realigned goals. - Tailor your explanation to the role, emphasizing how your experiences strengthen your candidacy. - Confidently own your unique career journey, understanding that a gap doesn't define you; it's how you navigate and learn from it that matters.  Have you considered the untapped potential of resume gaps? Individuals with extended breaks have secured remarkable roles by leveraging their distinctive strengths and experiences. Share your insights on uncovering the value within these gaps below!    â™»ï¸ Repost to inspire someone ğŸ”” Follow Kumud Deepali R. for daily hiring and motivational posts! â€¦more

A resume is a document that summarizes your skills, experience, and education. It is typically used to apply for jobs. Here are some tips on how to write a resume: * Choose a format. -â€----------------â€-â€------------- There are three main resume formats: chronological, functional, and combination. A chronological resume lists your work experience in reverse chronological order. A functional resume focuses on your skills and abilities. A combination resume combines elements of both chronological and functional resumes.  * Start with your contact information. --------------------------------------------------------------- This includes your name, address, phone number, and email address. * Write a resume objective or summary. A resume objective is a statement of your career goals. A resume summary is a brief overview of your skills and experience.  * List your work experience. ----------------â€------------------------------- For each job, include the company name, job title, dates of employment, and a brief description of your responsibilities.  * List your education. ------------------------------------- Include the name of the school, degree earned, and graduation date.  * List your skills. ------------------------------ This can include both hard skills (such as computer skills) and soft skills (such as communication skills).  * Proofread your resume carefully. ----------------â€----------------------------------------- Make sure there are no typos or grammatical errors.  * Tailor your resume to the specific job you are applying for. ------------------â€----------------------------------------------------- Highlight the skills and experience that are most relevant to the job. Here are some additional tips: * Use action verbs to describe your accomplishments. * Quantify your accomplishments whenever possible. * Keep your resume concise and easy to read. * Use a professional font and layout. -----------------------------------â€---------------------------------- â€¦more

The most common resume mistake I see when working with people:  Including a measurable result  ... that you literally can't measure.  ChatGPT does a great job pulling measurable results to put in your resume when you type in this prompt:  "What are some measurable accomplishments JOB POSITION can put in their resume?"  But it'll give you ideas that are clearly ChatGPT'd.  "Improved time from order to serving food by 25%"  Did you really time every order and calculate how much your "tailored customer service strategy reduced xyz"?  ...and was it really exactly a 25% increase?  Make sure you pick results that are measurable & more importantly TRUE  You can fully expect the interviewer to press you on "how exactly did you achieve this result?" Things are changing at a rapid pace in which updating your resume to appease to specific roles can be very expensive without the proper tools.

ğŸ’¡ Tips for Crafting a Winning Resume! ğŸš€  Your resume is your personal marketing tool. It needs to capture attention and showcase your skills and experience in the best light possible. Here are some essential tips to make your resume stand out:  1. Clear Contact Information Make sure your name, phone number, email address, and LinkedIn profile are easy to find. If you have a personal website or portfolio, include that too!  2. Compelling Professional Summary Kick things off with a brief but powerful summary of your experience, strengths, and career goals. This sets the tone for the rest of your resume.  3. Tailored Skills Section List relevant skills for the job you're applying for. Focus on a balance of both hard and soft skills that match the role.  4. Achievements Over Responsibilities Instead of just listing job duties, highlight your key achievements. Quantify your successes with numbers (e.g., increased sales by 30%, led a team of 5).  5. Experience That Shows Impact Describe your roles using action verbs and focus on the impact you made. This will demonstrate your contribution and value to potential employers.  6. Keep It Concise A resume should be no longer than 1-2 pages. Be concise and cut out unnecessary information. Employers often skim resumes, so make it easy for them to spot key details.  7. Education & Certifications List your degrees, certifications, and any additional training relevant to the job. Be sure to include dates and institutions.  8. Use Keywords Many companies use Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS) to scan resumes. Include keywords from the job description to ensure your resume gets noticed.  9. Formatting Is Key Keep your resume clean, professional, and easy to read. Top 5 resume tips that get you interviews:  1. Lead with the section of your resume with the most value.  Example: if you don't have any experience but have a Masters in Business Analytics, start your resume with your education section.  2. Show specific, numeric impact.  Example: Increased gross revenue by 3% as measure by...  âŒ don't use generic or fake percentages like 20% or 50%. If you cant measure impact, don't use a percentage.  3. Only include skills that you can validate.  Example: If you include Machine Learning in your skills section, you better have some machine learning project or experience in your resume.  4. Add the title you want to be on your resume.  Example: if you have done data analytics at a previous job, but you worked in operations, ask your previous manager if you can change the job title to data analyst on your linkedin and resume.  5. Use ğ—¯ğ—¼ğ—¹ğ—±ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ strategically.  âŒ don't bold skills âœ… bold your impact or outcome of a project  what important resume tips am I missing?  â€¦more
